Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to counsel a patient on her new prescription. It was my younger sister, her name flashing on the screen, and I remembered our argument from last night. She’d accused me of not listening, of always being too busy, and I’d promised myself I’d call her today, talk things through, rebuild the trust we’d always had. But now, in front of me, a woman waited anxiously, clutching her medication bag. She needed me to explain the side effects, to reassure her, to answer her questions with patience and care. My sister needed me to listen, to be her brother, to show her she mattered. My patient needed me to be her pharmacist, to guide her safely. Both expected my full attention, my empathy, my time—right now. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, my heart torn between the person who’d grown up with me and the stranger who depended on my expertise. I stared at my phone, then at the patient, feeling the impossible pull of being needed in two places at once.
